g.text: Among these three materials, only CsK
Sb is characterised by a direct band gap at
. The other two systems have an indirect band gap between X and
mum (VBM) and the conduction-band minimum (CBm) appear, respectively. This finding suggests that reducing
the relative amount of K leads to a shift of the VBM from the zone center
to the zone edge X. This feature has an
influence of the optical properties of the materials as well, as seen by the optical gaps reported in Table
Sb, where the optical and funda-
mental gaps coincide. Interestingly, the optical gap of Cs
Sb, being 1.53 eV, is only less than 100 meV smaller
Sb. Focusing more closely on the band structures, we notice that the dispersion of the valence
bands increases significantly going from Cs
Sb, where the valence is spread over an energy range of about 1 eV, to
Sb, where the highest-occupied bands extend over a region of almost 1.3 eV. While in the former case, and
KSb, the largest band dispersion occurs along the path connecting
, X, and W. In the band
) one of the valence bands has a pronounced minimum around L and an almost par-
abolic shape in the vicinity of this point, along the path connecting W to
. In the conduction region we notice
that the lowest unoccupied band in Cs
KSb does not cross the next one at higher energy, contrary to both Cs
Sb where this intersection is visible along the
The electronic properties of these three materials and their relation with the Cs-K ratio can be further analysed
by inspecting the band character. For this purpose, in Fig.
we report the most relevant atom-projected contribu-
tions to the bands of each material. While in all systems the valence bands are dominated by the partially filled Sb
), the conduction bands carry the signatures of each compound. An overview on Fig.
reveals that the bottom of the conduction region is dominated by the
-states of the Sb atoms and, to lesser extend,
also of the Cs atoms. This is not surprising, considering the parabolic shape of the lowest unoccupied band in the
vicinity of its minimum, which falls at the
point in each considered material. The electrons in the empty Sb 5
shell form these bands. Also electrons from the half-filled Cs 6
shell contribute to the conduction bands.
different colors are used to mark the contributions from inequivalent Cs atoms in Cs
) sites are displayed in red (orange). We notice that contributions from Cs
positions appear mainly in the lowest unoccupied band. On the other hand, Cs
contribute not only to the bottom of the conduction but also to higher unoccupied bands. In the other two com-
Sb, only one inequivalent Cs atoms is present. In both cases the Cs
to the lowest-unoccupied band in the vicinity of
-states in these materials are provided also to higher-energy unoccupied bands, especially around the
Sb). It should also be noted that in these systems
the contributions from K atoms enter into play in the conduction region
. In the bottom panels of Fig.
